name: (3Z)-3-{[chloro(phenyl)amino]methylidene}-1,7,7-trimethylbicyclo[2.2.1]heptan-2-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3090
Reason:
The starting point for the prediction is considering a similar compound without additional functional groups, cyclohexanone, which has a melting point of around 47°C. To this, we will add the effects of functional groups in the target compound:
- Phenyl group: +30 (due to increased molecular weight and pi stacking interactions)
- Chlorine substituent: +20 (due to larger atomic weight and potential dipole interactions)
- Amino group: -10 (it may introduce some polar character but also disrupt the crystal packing)
- Additional alkyl groups (methyl and methylene on the ring): +10 (increased molecular weight and hydrophobic bulk)
- Bicyclic system: +10 (increased rigidity and London dispersion forces)

Adding these effects to the base value of cyclohexanone gives us: 
47 (base value for cyclohexanone) + 30 (phenyl) + 20 (chlorine) - 10 (amino group) + 10 (additional alkyl groups) + 10 (bicyclic system) = 107°C.
Test (Predicted reason):
The base structure of bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane has a melting point of around 10°C. The introduction of a chloro group (Cl) increases the melting point due to the increase in molecular weight and the introduction of dipole-dipole interactions, estimated at +10°C. The amino group (NH2) can form hydrogen bonds, which significantly increases the melting point, estimated at +20°C. The ketone (C=O) group also contributes to an increase due to its polarity and potential for dipole-dipole interactions, estimated at +15°C. The methyl groups (CH3) add to the molecular weight and van der Waals forces, estimated at +5°C each, for a total of +15°C. The methylidene (CH2CH2) group adds to the molecular weight and van der Waals forces, estimated at +5°C. The presence of the bicyclic structure also contributes to the rigidity of the molecule, which can increase the melting point, estimated at +5°C.
